metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Are African American and Hispanics Disproportionately Affected by COVID-19 Because of Higher Obesity Rates? Title: Are African American and Hispanics Disproportionately Affected by COVID-19 Because of Higher Obesity Rates?

abstract.text: • Minority populations with COVID -19 have disproportionately higher mortality rates.
• The NYC boroughs with the highest mortality rates have the highest obesity rates.
• Obesity may play a role in the high mortality rates in minority populations.

body_text.text: Abstract: Introduction: On March 13, 2020 the WHO declared COVID-19 a pandemic. Shortly after that, it was reported that mortality rates in New York City (NYC), the epicenter of the pandemic in the United States, were found to be significantly higher in African American and Hispanics. The aim of this manuscript is to evaluate the mortality rates in NYC among the different ethnic groups and the different boroughs as it relates to the obesity rates to see whether this issue merits further evaluation. Methods: COVID-19 data was obtained from the official New York (NY) authorities in relation to total number of cases in the different boroughs of NYC. Age adjusted COVID-19 related mortality rates of the different ethnic groups were also obtained. This data was cross compared to historic community health data on obesity rates previously published and also obesity rates among the different ethnic groups in NYC.
body_text.section: Are African American and Hispanics Disproportionately Affected by COVID-19 Because of Higher Obesity Rates?

body_text.text: The two NYC boroughs that have the highest mortality rates are The Bronx (6%) and Brooklyn (5.4%). Both The Bronx and Brooklyn were also found to have the highest obesity rates 32% and 27% respectively. The two ethnic groups with the highest obesity rates (Hispanics and African Americans) were also found to have the highest age adjusted mortality rates per 100,000 compared to the other ethnic groups (22.8% and 19.8% respectively). Conclusion: Hispanics and African Americans in NYC seem to be disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic because of the higher incidence of mortality rates. Obesity may have played a role in the high incidence of mortality in those ethnic groups.

In December 2019, a novel coronavirus named SARS-CoV-2 was found to have caused an outbreak in Wuhan, China [1] . On March 13, 2020 the World Health Organization declared the SARS-Co-V-2 outbreak a pandemic. Coronavirus disease or COVID-19 as it's called can vary from mild flu like symptoms to severe ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome), multiple organ system failure (MOSF) and death [2] . To date no therapeutics have been proved effective for the treatment of severe illness caused by SARS-CoV-2 [3] . Mortality rates vary depending on the country of origin. The high mortality rates in Italy compared to other countries, for example, were explained by the fact that 23% of the Italian population were 65 years or older. In addition, compared to China, a much higher proportion of the infected population are older than 70 years old (37.6% compared to 11.9% in china) [4] . Another possible explanation of the high fatality rate in Italy is the high number of obese individuals among the elderly population [4, 5] . Given the high incidence of obesity among the American population this can have devastating consequences on the case fatality rates in the United States. Recently, it was reported that mortality rates in NYC, the epicenter of the pandemic in the United States, were found to be significantly higher in African Americans and Hispanics compared to other ethnic groups. The aim of this manuscript is to evaluate the mortality rates in NYC among the different ethnic groups and the different boroughs as it relates to the obesity rates to see whether this issue merits further evaluation.

Methods: Data was obtained from the official New York City Heath public website as it relates to the COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations and death. The data presented reflect the most recent information the health department has collected about people who have tested positive for COVID-19 in NYC. Death rate by race and ethnicity groups was most recently updated on April 6 th , 2020 and the overall number of COVID-19 confirmed cases, total number of hospitalizations and death rates were most recently updated on April 8 th , 2020 at 5:00 pm. The overall number of deaths on a daily basis starting March 8 th is shown in Figure 1 . The total number of cases in NYC and the COVID-19 mortality rates were also divided based on the five different boroughs of NYC (Figure 2 The breakdown of deaths per day is shown in Figure 1 . The two boroughs that have the highest mortality rates as shown in Figure 2 are The Bronx (6%) and Brooklyn (5.4%). Both The Bronx and Brooklyn were also found to have the highest obesity rates among the five boroughs, 32% and 27% respectively (Figure 3) . Age adjusted mortality rates divided based on race are shown in Figure 4 . Hispanics and African Americans had the highest age adjusted mortality rates per 100,000 compared to the other ethnic groups (22.8 and 19.8) (Figure 4) . Asians had the lowest mortality rate at 8.4%. Interestingly, Hispanics and African Americans had also higher obesity rates compared to the other ethnic groups (35.4% and 25.7%, P<0.05 respectively) as shown in Figure 5 .

Discussion: Patients who suffer from obesity are known to have obesity associated health conditions like diabetes mellitus, hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea and others which may contribute to higher mortality and morbidity [6] . Our prior experience with the impact of obesity on outcomes of patients infected with H1N1 influenza raises major concerns and should be taking into account while dealing with COVID-19 patients suffering from obesity [7] . In this observational study we noticed that the NYC boroughs with the highest mortality rates are the ones that suffer from high incidence of obesity among its adult population and that Hispanics and African Americans who have historically higher obesity rates are also disproportionately affected by higher age adjusted mortality rates compared to the other ethnic groups. Although we cannot make any definitive conclusions based on those observations, it's prudent to say that more work needs to be done to clearly elucidate the correlation between obesity and mortality rates secondary to COVID-19. It was also recently reported by the CDC in its weekly mortality and morbidity April 2020 report that hypertension, cardiovascular disease, chronic lung disease and diabetes mellitus are among the most common underlying conditions in hospitalized COVID-19 patients which are all known to be more prevalent in the obese patients. The effect of obesity on the high mortality rates can be explained by the presence of obesity related health conditions in individuals suffering from obesity, as mentioned previously, or by the fact that obesity was shown to be associated with poor lung function including high rates of obstructive sleep apnea, decreased expiratory reserve volume, decreased functional capacity and poor lung compliance [8] . The other explanation is possibly the increase in inflammatory cytokines in patients with obesity especially with new reports stating that cytokine storms are leading to some of the observed rapid deterioration of certain COVID 19 patients [2, 9, 10] . This observational study has multiple limitations. First, the data, although very recent, is being updated by government officials on a daily basis and given the lag in reports from laboratories the mortality rate reported herein can be an underestimation or overestimation based on the COVID-19 laboratory results. Second, to date we do not have de-identified data on the BMI and race of patients who succumbed to COVID-19, with more granular data from government officials we may be able to answer the question of whether obesity is directly associated with COVID-19 related deaths. Finally, NYC officials were discouraging patients with mild to moderate symptoms from being tested (this may be subject to change over time) so the data presented in this manuscript represent mostly patients with severe illness. Lastly. The age adjusted mortality rates per ethnicity group was missing data (data was complete in only 63% of reported deaths).

Health care providers need to be more vigilant in taking care of COVID-19 Hispanics and African Americans patients given the higher mortality rates in those ethnic groups. Obesity is more prevalent in Hispanics and Africans Americans and the two boroughs in NYC with the highest COVID-19 mortality rates have higher obesity rates. Obesity may be playing a role in the high incidence of mortality in certain ethnic groups.

FIGREF0.text: ). Adult obesity rates of the different boroughs were obtained from NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, Community Health Survey 2015-2016 (Figure 3). Age adjusted mortality rates for the different ethnic groups in NYC were derived from the Bureau of Communicable Disease Surveillance System as of April 6 th , 2020 and were reported based on ethnicity (Figure 4). Obesity and overweight data divided per ethnicity was obtained from NYC Bureau of Chronic Disease Evaluation and Research which released its obesity data in 2012. Data was collected between 2000 and 2010 as part of the Healthy People 2010 (HP 2010) project (Figure 5). Results: As of April 8 th the overall number of cases reported by the NYC Health was 80, 204. Among those cases 20,474 were hospitalized. The overall number of deaths was 4, 260.
